column1: The '''Lay of Leithian''' was a long [[Elvish]] lay that told the story of [[Beren]] and [[Lúthien]]
column3: and their return from [[Mandos]]. It was said to be the second longest of all such tales (with the longest being the ''[[Narn i Chîn Húrin (tale)|Narn i Chîn Húrin]]''

column1: [[File:Anke Eißmann - Beren recovers a Silmaril.jpg|thumb|left|200px|[[Anke Eißmann]] - ''Beren recovers a Silmaril'']]
The Lay tells the story of Beren's escape from [[Dorthonion]] after the loss of his father [[Barahir]]. Coming into the south
column2: he entered [[Doriath]] and came across [[Lúthien|Lúthien Tinúviel]] in the woods. They desired to wed
column5: set an impossible bride-price on his daughter—a [[Silmaril]] from the [[Iron Crown]] of [[Morgoth]] in the deepest pits of [[Angband]]. Beren set out on his hopeless quest with the aid of King [[Finrod|Finrod Felagund]]
column6: but they were captured and imprisoned by [[Sauron]]. Lúthien came to their aid through many troubles of her own
column7: and with the help of [[Huan the Hound]] she rescued Beren. Using her magical arts
column8: they penetrated Angband and stole one of the Silmarils
column9: but in their escape Beren's hand
column11: was bitten from his wrist by the great wolf [[Carcharoth]]. Eventually
column12: the wolf was hunted and slain
column14: but only at the cost of Beren's life. Then Lúthien
column17: and pleaded before Mandos himself. Both Beren and Lúthien were returned to life
column18: and they dwelt in the south of [[Ossiriand]] for a time. Lúthien had become mortal herself
column19: and she passed away at last with her beloved beyond the [[Circles of the World]].

column1: The Lay is not a mere literary invention — it does substantially exist in English
column2: in the form of iambic tetrameter
column3: and is contained within volume III of ''[[The History of Middle-earth]]''
column4: appropriately named ''[[The Lays of Beleriand]]''.  Though the extant lay runs to 4223 lines and fourteen [[Cantos of the Lay of Leithian|Cantos]]
column5: [[J.R.R. Tolkien|Tolkien]] never fully completed the poem.  The fragment terminates right at one of the climactic moments of the tale
column6: as Beren's hand is torn from the wrist by the monstrous guardian of Angband's gate

column1: The first recorded date of the writing of the Lay was at Line 557: August 23
column2: [[1925]].  The next date is two and a half years later
column5: at line 1161.  Over the next nine days he wrote fully 1769 lines
column6: up to 2929.  These dates are for the copying out of the manuscript
column8: so Tolkien may have had many passages earlier before he put them together.  In September
column10: he abandoned the Lay.  He sent it to [[C.S. Lewis]]

column3: taken from the slain'].  I can quite honestly say that it is ages since I have had an evening of such delight: and the personal interest of reading a friend's work had very little to do with it.  I should have enjoyed it just as well as if I'd picked it up in a bookshop

column1: Later he wrote a detailed criticism
column2: which pretends to treat the Lay as if it were a historical document.  Tolkien was influenced by Lewis' comments
column3: and made several minor changes based on them.

column1: Leithian means "''Release from bondage''" from the verb ''[[leithia]]'' "release" from verb ''[[leith]]'' "set free" ([[root]] [[LEK]])<ref>{{HM|Etymologies}}
The exact derivation of the word is peculiar since it is the only occurrence of a verb becoming a noun simply with the ending -n
column2: although it could be related to the [[Primitive Quendian]] ending such as ''[[-nê]]
column4: the noun ''leithian'' is derived from an earlier [[Old Sindarin]] *''lektiane''.{{fact}}

column1: The most likely meaning of the title can be found at one of the key moments in the poem
column2: the point at which one of the Silmarils
column4: is cut from the crown of [[Morgoth]] by Beren:

column1: ''before the sun and moon were born
''thus out of bondage came at last
''from iron to mortal hand it passed.''<sup>''[[The Lays of Beleriand]]''
This moment is also central to the over-arching story-line of ''[[The Silmarillion]]''
column2: in which the gem is used to bring hope to the scattered peoples of Middle-Earth and is ultimately set in the heavens by the mariner [[Eärendil]] as a sign of their coming salvation.

column1: The name of the poem is therefore likely an attempt to underscore the importance of the Lay relative to other tales from the first age.  Though honor
column2: bravery and vengeance drive the Elven hosts forward to war with [[Morgoth]]
column3: it is only love that can overcome all obstacles to wrest a [[Silmaril]] from his crown.
